title: 1995 ARL season
text:
The 1995 ARL premiership was the 88th season of professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> football in Australia, and the first to be run by the <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League">Australian Rugby League</a> following the hand-over of the Premiership's administration by the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League">New South Wales Rugby League</a>. For the first time since the <a href="1988%20NSWRL%20season">1988 NSWRL season</a>, the Premiership expanded again, and for the first time ever outside the borders of New South Wales and Queensland, with the addition of four new clubs from <a href="North%20Queensland">North Queensland</a>, <a href="WA%20Reds">Western Australia</a>, <a href="South%20Queensland%20Crushers">South Queensland</a>
and <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>. This saw a total of twenty teams, the largest number in the League's history, compete during the regular season for the <a href="J%20J%20Giltinan%20Shield">J J Giltinan Shield</a>, which was followed by a series of play-off finals between the top eight teams that culminated in a <a href="grand%20final">grand final</a> for the <a href="Winfield%20Cup">Winfield Cup</a> between the newly re-branded <a href="Sydney%20Bulldogs">Sydney Bulldogs</a> and the <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles</a>.
The 1995 season also saw the first major consequences of the <a href="Super%20League%20war">Super League war</a>, with the ARL's refusal to select players from the eight clubs (which included every club that had won the premiership since 1988) for <a href="1995%20State%20of%20Origin%20series">State of Origin</a> or <a href="Test%20match%20%28rugby%20league%29">Test matches</a>, including the <a href="1995%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1995 Rugby League World Cup</a>, who had aligned with <a href="News%20Ltd">News Ltd</a>'s proposed <a href="Super%20League%20%28Australia%29">Super League</a>.
Season summary.
1995 would prove to be a year of massive change for the League. In addition to the introduction of four new teams, it was the last year of the premiership's association with <a href="Rothmans%20International%20plc">Rothmans</a> and the Winfield brand and consequently the final year that clubs competed for the <a href="Winfield%20Cup">Winfield Cup</a>.
The storm clouds that had been gathering for some time in the form of rumours and speculation about <a href="Super%20League%20%28Australia%29">Super League</a> were to break on 1 April 1995 with a verification that would rain on the game with more force than anyone could have expected. The subsequent <a href="Super%20League%20war">Super League war</a> would rock the sport in Australia and set it back almost a decade in terms of its loss of public support and damage to its grass roots values.
The 1995 season was played in front of a background of legal actions, breaking friendships and with clubs, players and managers all jockeying for position and self-interest. Players who had signed with the new <a href="Super%20League%20%28Australia%29">Super League</a> venture were forbidden by the ARL from participating in the <a href="1995%20State%20of%20Origin">1995 State of Origin</a>. Queensland and New South Wales selectors were limited to selecting players only from ARL-aligned clubs.
The usual twenty-two regular season rounds were played from March till August. However the large number of teams meant a resulting top eight would battle it out in the finals rather than the usual five. These were Manly, Canberra, Brisbane, Cronulla, Newcastle, Sydney Bulldogs, St. George and North Sydney (who made it in due to Auckland being penalised for an interchange infringement).
Cronulla-Sutherland's halfback <a href="Paul%20Green%20%28rugby%20league%29">Paul Green</a> was awarded the 1995 <a href="Rothmans%20Medal">Rothmans Medal</a>. The <a href="Dally%20M%20Award">Dally M Award</a> was given to Canberra's five-eighth, <a href="Laurie%20Daley">Laurie Daley</a> who was also named "<a href="Rugby%20League%20Week">Rugby League Week</a>'s" player of the year. Manly-Warringah's <a href="Steve%20Menzies">Steve Menzies</a> became the first <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a> for 50 years to top the season's try-scoring list, while his teammate <a href="Matthew%20Ridge">Matthew Ridge</a> set a club point scoring record of 257 points (11 tries, 106 goals and 1 field goal) to be the league's leading point scorer for the year.
By the end of the regular season, the ARL's inaugural 20-team competition had set a new record for aggregate match attendances of 3,061,338.
Advertising.
1995 marked the final year of the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League">New South Wales Rugby League</a>'s sponsorship arrangement with <a href="Rothmans%20International%20plc">Rothmans</a> and <a href="Winfield%20%28cigarette%29">Winfield</a> due to the <a href="Government%20of%20Australia">Federal Government</a>'s blanket ban on cigarette advertising in Australia effective from 1 January 1996. It was consequently the final year of a seven-year association with <a href="Tina%20Turner">Tina Turner</a> and the end of an era in Australian sports marketing. 
As in 1994 the New South Wales Rugby League and its advertising agency Hertz Walpole returned to the original 1989 recording of <a href="The%20Best%20%28song%29">The Best</a> by Turner to underscore the season launch advertisement. Footage from the studio <a href="Chroma%20key">bluescreen</a> shoot taken during Turner's 1993 Sydney visit was used in the final advertisements. The enduring images are of Turner performing the song on an elevated stage in front of the fluttering banners of the 20 clubs that would participate in 1995's expanded competition.
Teams.
When the Australian Rugby League began taking bids for additional teams to begin playing in 1995, it was expected that only two teams would enter. The <a href="Auckland%20Warriors">Auckland Warriors</a> were the first club to be accepted, with the final place being fought for by <a href="South%20Queensland%20Crushers">South Queensland</a>, <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland</a> and <a href="WA%20Reds">Perth</a>. The Australian Rugby League later announced that all three clubs had been accepted, taking the number of teams from 16 in <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League%20season%201994">1994</a> to 20 in 1995, the highest it had ever been and would ever be.
With the addition of the <a href="Auckland%20Warriors">Auckland Warriors</a>, <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland Cowboys</a>, <a href="South%20Queensland%20Crushers">South Queensland Crushers</a> and <a href="Western%20Reds">Western Reds</a> the 1995 season involved an unprecedented twenty clubs, including five <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>-based foundation teams, another six from <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>, one from <a href="Newcastle%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Newcastle</a>, one from <a href="Wollongong">Wollongong</a> two from <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a>, one from <a href="Gold%20Coast%2C%20Queensland">Gold Coast</a>, one from <a href="Townsville">Townsville</a>, one from <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>, one from <a href="Canberra">Canberra</a> and one from <a href="Perth">Perth</a>, who all contested the premiership, making it the largest competition in terms of participation in Australia's history.
With the storm that would be the <a href="Super%20League%20war">Super League war</a> already brewing in the background, three clubs based in Sydney suburbs, in an effort to position themselves favourably as battle lines were being drawn up, re-branded themselves for the 1995 season with less geographically distinct names: the Balmain Tigers became the 'Sydney Tigers', the Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs became the 'Sydney Bulldogs', and the Eastern Suburbs Roosters became the 'Sydney City Roosters'.
Finals.
A new finals system involving eight teams instead of the previous five was introduced for the expanded 1995 competition. The final eight was to be made of four clubs who would ultimately prove loyal to the Australian Rugby League (<a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah</a>, <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George</a>, <a href="North%20Sydney%20Bears">North Sydney</a> and <a href="Newcastle%20Knights">Newcastle</a>) and four clubs who would join Super League's rebel ranks (<a href="Canterbury%20Bulldogs">Sydney Bulldogs</a>, <a href="Canberra%20Raiders">Canberra</a>, <a href="Brisbane%20Broncos">Brisbane</a> and <a href="Cronulla-Sutherland%20Sharks">Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks</a>). The Grand Final was played out by a team from each faction, being the Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles and the Sydney Bulldogs.
Grand Final.
Having finished in sixth place at the end of the regular season, the Bulldogs managed a history-making finals surge, winning three sudden death matches to make the grand final. Canterbury were ahead at half-time 6-4. They lost the scrum count 3-5 and the penalty count 9-10. Manly's 22-3 season win/loss record was the best not to have secured the premiership.
At game's end Lamb enjoyed the rare honour of celebrating as a retiring victorious skipper, although he surprisingly returned for the <a href="1996%20ARL%20season">1996 season</a>.
The performance of Eddie Ward, refereeing his first grand final, was subject to some post match controversy.
<a href="Rugby%20League%20Week">Rugby League Week</a> commented: "Two of Canterbury's three tries appeared to have resulted from borderline passes, another came on the seventh tackle, and a fourth - which in fact was a fair try - was disallowed"
Sydney Bulldogs 17 (Tries: Price, Hughes, Silva. Goals: Halligan 2/5. Field Goal: Lamb.)
Manly-Warringah 4 (Goals: Ridge 2/2.)
